intro: Lavandula sampaioana, commonly known as the São Paulo lavender, is a species of flowering plant in the mint family, Lamiaceae. It is native to Brazil and is characterized by its compact, upright growth habit and aromatic, gray-green foliage. The plant produces spikes of pale purple to violet flowers that bloom in the spring and summer seasons. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it suitable for rock gardens and xeriscaping. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
